<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
_MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the code fragment does not directly call any <string.h> function. The macro/function _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY is not one of the standard string.h routines listed in MISRA Rule 21.17. In addition, it is called with pool->memory and pool->size, and preceding assertions indicate the pool memory and size are consistent with the allocation, so there is no indication of an access beyond the bounds. (If _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY were implemented using a string.h function like memset/memcpy, it would still be safe here provided it uses the pointer and size that match the allocated region; only an implementation that used a larger size or an invalid pointer would violate the rule.)
